identical sequences that occur within nucleic acid sequences (such as RNA and
DNA sequences), protein sequences, protein structures or polymeric carbohydrates
across species (orthologous sequences) or within different molecules produced by
the same organism (paralogous sequences). In the case of cross species
conservation, this indicates that a particular sequence may have been maintained
by evolution despite speciation. The further back up the phylogenetic tree a
particular conserved sequence may occur the more highly conserved it is said to
be. Since sequence information is normally transmitted from parents to progeny
by genes, a conserved sequence implies that there is a 'conserved gene'.

It is widely believed that mutation in a "highly conserved" region leads to a
non-viable life form, or a form that is eliminated through natural selection.
